heading: universal promises sdmi music
subheading: universal music plans to put its tunes into sdmi devices and services when they arrive. it also promises support, but isn't getting specific yet.
author: wired news report
text: universal, one of the "big five" music labels, promised tuesday that its music will play on portable digital music devices this winter. universal music group said it will deliver titles through the rioport, a walkman-like device that protects music from piracy using the secure digital music initiative, or sdmi."this is an important first step in recognizing the tremendous potential of the digital music market," said larry kenswil, president of universal's e-commerce group, in a statement.the news isn't a surprise, since the controversial sdmi, still in development, is designed to meet the single biggest desire of the major record labels regarding digital music distribution: securing their material from illegal copying.the deal -- which is more of a promise than a specific agreement -- calls for music delivery through the rioport.com web site and rio brand digital music players.read wired news' ongoing mp3 coverage
